critique: This executive order establishes a security clearance program for US citizens employed by NATO, SEATO, and CENTO. It aims to protect classified information while also recognizing individual rights. The order delegates authority to the Secretary of Defense to establish and administer the program. It references Executive Order No. 10865, indicating a continuation of existing security procedures. The order balances national security concerns with individual liberties, but ultimately prioritizes security. There is no clear indication of a liberal or conservative ideological tilt. The order does not directly address immigration. It expands executive power by creating a new program under the Secretary of Defense. It does not significantly impact federalism. It leans towards national security by establishing security clearance procedures. It does not directly address economic regulation or social inclusion.
